The Cheatham County Literacy Council, in collaboration with the Cheatham County School District, will host the first of five planned “Story Walks” at the East Cheatham Elementary School walking track on Saturday, Sept. 12.

These FREE family engagement activities are designed to get families out into the great outdoors, meet some of our dedicated community partners and enjoy a quality children’s book selection together.

At ECES on Saturday, the engaging children’s book, “Knots on a Counting Rope,” will be recreated in a series of sequential story boards at the track.

Families and students will walk the story path while reading sections of the story, answer comprehension questions from community volunteers, and collect a bead for a story retelling bracelet. At the end of the walk, students will use the collected beads to retell the story.

All social distancing protocols will be followed to ensure the safety of participants.

In the Cheatham County School District’s reopening plan, it was stated that if a positive COVID-19 case was identified within the district, we would close down the identified school for two days.

Again, if you have any health-related questions or concerns, please reach out to one of our school nurses or Shelley Duke, the district’s Supervisor of Coordinated Health Services.

The Tennessee Department of Education and Trevecca University recently announced a new resource, “Bridging the Distance: Family Remote Learning,” which is specially designed to help families navigate remote learning and better understand the common tools and programs used by educators.

This free resource features “Remote Learning 101” modules that will help families learn the same tools our educators use for remote instruction.

These short, accessible videos from experts will help families understand common remote learning tools and equips them to speak the same “tech” language as the teacher, so they will be better able to support their child’s learning.

Families can access these resources at: https://remotefamilylearning.com/

Bridging the Distance covers four essential types of tools families and students encounter during remote learning — learning management systems, communications platforms, video platforms and group discussion platforms.

Cheatham County, only 67% of us have filled out our 2020 Census.

If you have not already done so, you can submit your census online by visiting: https://my2020census.gov.

The U.S. Census Bureau recently announced that data collection will now end Sept. 30 to ensure enough time to process data by the statutory deadline of Dec. 31.

The results of the 2020 Census will help determine how hundreds of billions of dollars in federal funding flow into communities every year for the next decade.

For schools, that means the numbers are used to make decisions to support programs and services such as Title I resources, free and reduced-price lunch, special education, teacher training, classroom technology, after-school programs and more.

Students enrolled in the Cheatham County School District’s daycare program are having a fun and safe summer!

Since May 26, we have successfully operated the program in five elementary schools.

Under the leadership of Daycare Supervisor Emily Staggs and our site directors, our daycares have taken numerous precautions in light of COVID-19 to ensure the health and safety of the more than 165 students enrolled in the program.

In fact, Staggs’ plan for reopening our daycares this summer after a two-month closure from March-May was shared with school districts across the state, and many of them modeled their daycare reopening plans after ours.

We have provided a safe and fun learning environment for our students, and we are assured that this will continue when we open our schools in August.

Buses will be parked at six locations across Cheatham County for the community to drop off school supplies.

Buses will be located at Walmart in Ashland City, Dollar General in Kingston Springs, Dollar General in Pegram, Dollar General Market in Pleasant View, Dollar General on Bearwallow Road (East Cheatham), Dollar General on Neptune Road and Highway 12 North (West Cheatham).

The district is asking that you purchase school supplies and bring them to the bus on this date. Staff members will be on hand to collect your supplies and stuff them on the bus.

Once all of the supplies are collected, they will be divided among all Cheatham County schools and be given to students who need supplies for the upcoming school year.

The Cheatham County School District has named Bethany Jenkins as the new academic specialist at Kingston Springs Elementary School.

Jenkins, a Nashville native, received both her bachelor’s and master’s degrees from The University of Tennessee-Knoxville.

She is currently working toward attaining her Doctor of Education degree from Lipscomb University, with an anticipated graduation date of December 2021.

For the last three years, Jenkins has served as an elementary instructional coach for Metro Nashville Public Schools. Prior to this role, she taught both first and fourth grades for Metro Nashville Public Schools.

“I’m excited to join the Kingston Springs Elementary family and am looking forward to building relationships with the students, staff and families within the Cheatham County community,” she said.

She lives in West Nashville with her husband and two dogs.

We want to congratulate Cheatham County Central High School senior Brandon Chandler for earning his associate degree and high school diploma at the same time!

Brandon earned his degree from Austin Peay State University through a collaborative between APSU and the Cheatham County School District.

He joins Sycamore High School seniors Hannah Turner and Catie McLachlan in achieving this huge accomplishment.

The collaborative, which was launched in August 2018, is an academic initiative of the district’s five-year strategic plan.

As part of the district’s partnership with APSU, students were able to take college classes, which were taught by APSU faculty members, over the past two years.

Thanks to both of them and to Brentwood Academy for adding this fun aspect to the parade!

As part of the Cheatham County School District’s five-year plan, the district identified the need to conduct a communications survey with our stakeholders to measure communications effectiveness at both the school and district level.

In addition, we want to hear from our stakeholders about our communication for COVID-19 distance learning and how we can improve this method of learning moving forward.

We are asking that parents, students and staff members take a few minutes to complete the short survey.

The survey has been emailed to parents and staff members, and there’s been a great response so far. If you haven’t responded to the survey yet, it can be found on our website at https://bit.ly/35CD4hD.

The survey will close on Friday, May 22 at 8 a.m.

Good news … Our three high schools will have a prom after all since the original ones had to be postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

• Cheatham County business owner Valerie Kemp is organizing a prom for Cheatham County Central High School and it will tentatively be held Friday, July 17 beginning at 7 p.m. at The Adalea in Chapmansboro. Kemp and other businesses and community members are sponsoring the prom.

• Harpeth High School will host its prom Thursday, July 16 at 7 p.m. in the school’s gym.

• Sycamore High School parents and community members are organizing and raising money for a prom and it will tentatively be held Friday, July 10 beginning at 7 p.m. at Clementine Hall in Nashville.

Please note that the CCCHS and SHS proms are not school-sponsored.

Also, if the state of Tennessee or CDC determines that large gatherings are not allowed on those dates, then the proms may need to be adjusted or canceled.

Friday was National School Lunch Hero Day!

The Cheatham County School District is beyond grateful to the individuals who ensure our students receive nutritious meals.

In recent weeks, these folks have been on the frontline ensuring children in our community are fed during the extended COVID-19 closure. To date, we have served more than 53,000 meals.

On Friday, 877 children received 7,016 meals.

As part of National School Lunch Hero Day, some of our families dropped off gifts for our School Nutrition staff to thank them for their hard work and dedication.

Specifically, Cheatham Middle School organized an effort to gift Origami Owl jewelry to our workers.

Our next food distribution is Tuesday, May 5 from 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.

Distribution sites are Pegram Elementary Fine Arts Magnet School, Ashland City Elementary School and East Cheatham Elementary School.

While schools have been closed due to COVID-19, employees from IES, the Cheatham County School District’s maintenance contractor, have been busy working on a number of capital projects.

In May 2019, the Cheatham County Commission approved funds that allows the district to make school maintenance upgrades over a three-year period.

Some of the projects that have recently been completed include new theatre seating and carpet at Harpeth High School and Sycamore High School; new bottle filling stations at Sycamore High School and Ashland City Elementary School; and gym bathroom renovations at Ashland City Elementary School.

Additionally, a new cafeteria serving line was installed at East Cheatham Elementary School. It replaced the line that was original to the school, which opened in 1957.

Additional projects throughout the district are in the works.

Due to our closure for COVID-19, the Cheatham County School District has been working on alternative plans for both our Pre-K and Kindergarten registrations for the 2020-2021 school year.

The district will release additional information about the process for both registrations the week of May 3.

Also, will your child miss the cutoff of Aug. 15, 2020, to attend kindergarten next school year?

If so and they turn 5 years old by Sept. 30, 2020, they still have an opportunity to qualify for early access to enter kindergarten.

All children must go through an application process in order to be identified as highly-advanced for early access. This equates to grade acceleration or skipping a grade.

The deadline to submit the application has been extended. Students who might qualify for early access will need to be tested and additional testing information will be provided at a later date when school is back in session.

To learn more about the process and the application for early access to kindergarten, visit https://bit.ly/3dZU59l or email sarah.green@ccstn.org.

In case you missed it ... what a great opportunity for our students!

The Tennessee Department of Education has secured a partnership with the state’s PBS stations to deliver daily instructional content for Tennessee students during COVID-19 school closures.

This partnership will provide all students with access to daily learning opportunities right in their own homes.

Staring April 6, Tennessee’s six PBS stations, including WNPT in Nashville — will deliver two hours of programming with high-quality instructional content from 10 a.m. to noon.

Four hours of content will also be streamed overnight, which viewers can watch live or record.

The content will be developed and provided by Tennessee educators in partnership with the Tennessee Department of Education and meets a critical need to ensure all students have access to high-quality learning opportunities, regardless if their home has internet connectivity or capable devices.

The Tennessee Department of Education has secured a partnership with the state’s PBS stations to deliver daily instructional content for Tennessee students during COVID-19 school closures.

This partnership will provide all students with access to daily learning opportunities right in their own homes.

Staring April 6, Tennessee’s six PBS stations, including WNPT in Nashville — will deliver two hours of programming with high-quality instructional content from 10 a.m. to noon.

Four hours of content will also be streamed overnight, which viewers can watch live or record.

The content will be developed and provided by Tennessee educators in partnership with the Tennessee Department of Education and meets a critical need to ensure all students have access to high-quality learning opportunities, regardless if their home has internet connectivity or capable devices.

Congrats to Sycamore High School senior Daniel Saylor, who was recently named a National Merit Scholarship finalist.

Daniel was among the top 1 percent of 2020 U.S. high school seniors to achieve semifinalist distinction in September 2019.

Of the 16,000 students selected nationwide as semifinalists, 90 percent (roughly 15,000) were chosen to be finalists. They are eligible to vie for about 7,600 National Merit Scholarships worth approximately $31 million that will be announced beginning in April.

To become a finalist, semifinalists must have an outstanding academic record throughout high school, receive an endorsement/recommendation from their high school principal and earn SAT scores that confirm their previous test performances.

Semifinalists must also submit an essay and detailed application, which demonstrate their participation and leadership in their schools and communities.

Daniel, who made a 35 on the ACT, plans to attend the University of Alabama-Huntsville, where he will study engineering and play basketball.

The 2020 Census is here, and the Cheatham County School District needs every family in our district to participate.

Our communities and schools depend on it.

Specifically, the census count affects services that impact our students and families, such as:

• Special education, after-school programs and classroom technology
• Food assistance, including free and reduced-price school lunches
• Child health and maternal health programs

Our families should have received a census form in the mail.

The form is short and can be filled out online, over the phone or with a paper form.

All information is protected and no law enforcement agency (local, state or federal) can access census data for any reason.

For more information, visit www.census.gov.

Six high school students from Cheatham County joined hundreds of their peers from across Tennessee in Murfreesboro today to express their views on public education in the state.

The six attended the Tennessee School Boards Association’s Student Congress on Policies in Education (SCOPE) conference.

The conference took place on the Middle Tennessee State University campus.

Cheatham County Central High School delegates were William Angeles and Ansley Pfeffer.

Harpeth High School delegates were Halee McKaskle and Mallary McKaskle.

Sycamore High School delegates were Gracie Butler and Chelsea Stricklin.

The chaperones were Kathryn VanMater (CCCHS), Lee Rector (HHS) and Maggie Fields (SHS).

SCOPE is designed to give students a voice where public education issues are concerned and to involve young people in finding solutions to the topics that are discussed.

Cheatham County Central High School students were invited to see a performance of the hit Broadway phenomenon, “Hamilton,” on Thursday at the Tennessee Performing Arts Center in Nashville.

In order to qualify for this invitation, students were required to take part in a 3-5 day lesson on Alexander Hamilton.

They were then to create an original skit, monologue, poem or song about the Founding Era that incorporated information from primary source documents.

Thanks to the generosity of the Gilder-Lehrman Institute of American History, students were able to see the play for only $10.

The Hamilton Education Program selected CCCHS students Landon Hunter, Jerry Reed and Dillon Vance as one of 15 student projects to be presented on stage in front of all 38 schools attending.

The group was given backstage access, met with the Hamilton cast and performed their original work on the set of Hamilton. Later, they were interviewed by local media.

A huge shout out to CCCHS history teacher Spencer Cooke for making this opportunity happen!

Second District Cheatham County School Board member Kimberly Messer has resigned from the Board to take the resource coordinator position at Riverside Academy.

Due to her resignation, the Cheatham County Commission will appoint an individual to fill the Second District vacancy until the general election on Aug. 6, 2020.

Individuals who are interested need to submit in writing their request to be considered for the position to the County Clerk, 354 Frey St., Suite F, Ashland City, TN 37015 within seven days prior to the next Commission meeting on Jan. 27, 2020.

Individuals wishing to be considered may also submit their name and qualifications to the Commission chairman at the meeting. Members of the Commission may also submit names for consideration at the time of the meeting.

To be considered, an individual must be a resident of the Second District and possess a high school degree or GED.

Mrs. Messer had served on the board since 2014 and served as chairwoman for two years. We truly appreciate her dedicated service to the district!

An exciting, weeklong summer adventure awaits students entering grades K-6 with activities that explore connections between science, technology, engineering and innovation while sharpening their 21st century learning skills.

Pleasant View Elementary School teacher Abby Hager will serve as the camp director.

Registration is now open at www.campinvention.org, and every registration includes a complimentary Camp Invention T-shirt.

The Cheatham County School District will be closed Tuesday, Dec. 10 and Wednesday, Dec. 11.

Absences have been closely tracked for both students and staff, and flu and stomach virus illnesses have caused a concern.

While our schools are closed, our custodial team will be cleaning and disinfecting all buildings.

Therefore, no one will be allowed in the schools. Our daycares will be closed both days, and all after-school and extracurricular activities such as sporting events will not be held.

The Centers for Disease Control reports that the flu is now being considered widespread in Tennessee, and the flu has started a bit earlier and more aggressively than it does this time of year.

While we are closed, we encourage parents and guardians to use this time to clean their children’s personal items such as backpacks, jackets and lunchboxes.
